user_review: Great food and service! Several members of our party have food allergies (gluten, onions, garlic, peppers) and we though we'd never find a French restaurant in Montreal that would accommodate us, and we were happily proved wrong! They have gluten-free bread and multiple choices on the menu that were celiac-friendly. We had smoked salmon with truffle oil, capers, and fennel and a salad as an appetizer. Both duck dishes (confit duck leg and the maple-glazed duck breast) and the grilled salmon were gluten-free, cooked and seasoned perfectly. They were served with seasonal vegetables, lightly grilled and steamed. The location of the restaurant is perfect if you want to spend the day walking around Old Montreal and go to dinner nearby. However, the entrance is a little difficult to see, you have to enter through the main hotel entrance and then turn right to go into the restaurant. The restaurant itself is beautifully decorated and has some thematic Napoleon art (we were seated near a painting of The Coronation of Napoleon). All the staff we encountered were friendly and courteous, which made ordering with food allergies very easy.Overall, I highly recommend this restaurant, be sure to get a reservation ahead of time to secure a table!
Wonderful experience with authentic French restaurant. Very romantic restaurant and server was great and formal service.

Amazing service. Great food, for the most part. Also, coming from DC, the food prices weren't bad at all for the high class food. The smoked salmon was a bit too salty but still enjoyable. The beef tartare was delicious but my fiancee was bothered by how the serving plating looked too similar to a burger patty. It also should be listed as an appetizer instead of an entree. It was good but after a few bites, it just gets boring. Meanwhile, the snail tartine was flavorful and delicious with a great proportion of flaky puff pastry and chunks of snail. Lastly, the duck breast was perfectly cooked, both tender and packed with flavor. There was an array of vegetables on the plate from carrots, potatoes, green beans, and peas which all gave various delicious crunches.

A feast fit for a King! A sumptuous atmosphere, coupled with French flair and delicious cuisine make for a standout night to remember. My husband and I both ordered the tasting menu, and we were not disappointed. It started off with a lobster bisque soup, homemade smoked salmon, shrimp and scallops, a pallet cleansing sorbet infused with Prosecco, steak and desert medley/coffee. It was a decadent feast for the senses. Dishes are so elegantly presented. For instance, the smoked salmon is presented as a flower!Restaurant is housed in the beautiful, ornate Bonaparte Hotel in Old Montreal. Be prepared to be wowed.

Don't know how to say but I'm a little disappointed. The service is good but I totally didn't get the food. The lobster soup and ravioli are really delicious, then nothing special. The duck breast is just average and the foie gras, I don't know why many people recommend it - it's too greasy for me. The cocktail Le Manhattan i think is not suitable for girls since it's too strong.And what impressed me is that I don't why their desserts are bitter, including the caramel pudding and the three mousses.ThusI'd suggest order separately rather than take the tasting menu.

We did two 7-courses.Pic1: salad, smoked salmon, snails, sorbet, sole fillet, desert.Salad is nothing special.Smoked salmon is delicious and flavorful.Snails is ordinary.Sorbet is very good and refreshing with taste of alcohol and pear.Sole fillet is home style. Dessert is ordinary.Pic2: lobster soup, foie Gras creme brulee, mushroom ravioli, sorbet ,fillet mignon , dessert The best is foie gras creme brulee and fillet mignon.It's a very busy restaurant. All the people who work there are stressful. As a customer you could feel it and I don't quite enjoy that. But it worth a try

Lovely classy serene spot in old Montreal with quality food. I needed a break after walking all morning and wanted something light ... and a glass of Prosecco. They have a two course lunch menu with a choice of appetizer and price based on what kind of main you get. I wasn't hungry enough so just got a salad and shrimp/scallop appetizer. The food was great! I can taste the butter yum. Servers were very attentive and the ambiance was what I needed :).

Amazing quality food.  Service was over the top.  Everyone was over the top friendly from the moment we walked in to the second we walked out.Food flavors are in-describable. The second you take a bite the flavors work their way up to a powerful but not overwhelming peak...then you're left begging for more.

We had 5 courses menu with price $86 and we all felt really worthy to try! Everything is amazingly good except desert. The lobster bisque and duck foie gras creme brûlée are our favorites. Our entrees were tasty with reasonable portion especially our beef filet mignon was juicy cooked in medium rare. Only complaint was the dessert it was not delicate at all and didn't match all the courses we had before it.

I generally do not have the opportunity to eat a lot of French food so I do not really have a benchmark restaurant to compare this one too, but for the most part, I found the food enjoyable and the service excellent.The waiters and waitresses do speak English although there is a bit of an accent (This is a French speaking province after all).  Nevertheless, they provided great service and were very attentive and patient with my fruitless efforts to pronounce French foods.  For my more gluttonous Americans, the stigma about French food being a big plate with small portions does hold true, but they give you unlimited bread to satisfy your cravings.The food is tasty! My family and I split the Duck Foie Gras with Creme Brulee (which is like a pâté) which was delicious.  Rich and filled with flavor.  The pear and gingerbread seemed like an odd combination at first, but it worked really well.I ordered the duck confit, but I got to try other dishes as well so I will give a few words about those as well.Duck Confit- The skin was buttery and rich, the meat was tender and well flavored, and all the vegetables were cooked beautifully. Duck Breast- This is the first time I've had duck breast and it was a bit too chewy and tough for my liking.  The flavor was decent at first, but by the time you are done chewing its mostly bland.Veal- The veal is very tender and has a great bite to it, but it needs salt and seasoning.Steak Tartare- The steak tartare tasted incredibly fresh.  It has a nice citrus flavoring which contrasts nicely with the heaviness of the fries.  Overall a good restaurant!

Located in the old port of Montreal, Restaurant Bonaparte is one of the best French cuisine rated by yelpers. The environment is very French inspired, and the waiter is very attentive and polite. The waiter introduced both tasting menu, one is 4 courses menu and then other is 7 courses menu. I pick the 7 courses menu including the Souffle dessert. With the price of $86, I believe it is a very good deal because it is way cheaper than Toronto. I start with Lobster Bisque, then smoke salmon appetizer, coming to the third course is the shrimp and scallop with vanilla sauce, then I have the pear sorbet to clean my mouth, the main course is the duck breast, and finally finished with chocolate chip Souffle with tea or coffee or hot lemon water.  I did ordered another seafood and fish linguine, and it is not than enough for 2 of us. All the courses are great, but the most memorable one that stand out is the duck breast, the sauce is so tasty and the duck is so tender. I did tell the waiter that it is the best duck breast I ever had, much better than the ones in Toronto. The only thing is the seafood and fish linguine lacks a bit sauce and flavor. I would definitely recommend anyone at Montreal should have dinner at least once in this restaurant.

Came here a second time because I loved their mushroom ravioli the first time around.Same quality, and pretty much almost the same menu. You have several options in each course, so if you're craving one type of meat/vegetable over the other, than you can choose that and not be restrained to a typical fixed menu.Wine list is great, and their sommelier can give their best recommendation.Dressy atmosphere, and you can do reservations, but I'm pretty sure you can walk in as well.Very nice date place.

My family and I wanted to experience a French fine dining meal at least once on our trip to Montreal. After sifting through numerous reviews, we selected Bonaparte. We don't regret it at all.The service here is amazing! The servers are very friendly and efficient. They make you feel welcome and always check to see if you have enough water or if you enjoy the food. The service is kind of slow, but that's to be expected at a restaurant such as this, since they make everything to order. The portions are fairly large, and the food is delicious. Everything we tried had so much flavor. We ordered two appetizers-- the onion soup and the escargot. The escargot was plated beautifully and tasted excellent. The onion soup came with cheese bread, which had a sharp flavor and picked up the soup wonderfully. For entrées, my family got the salmon and the scallops, both of which came with various vegetables and were well received. I ordered the filet mignon, and it was the best I'd ever had. The sauce was plentiful and rich, the peppercorn adding a nice kick. The meat was juicy and tender. And the fries were crisp and soft, though I wish they'd been seasoned more.We were too full for dessert, but the menu was extensive, and we saw other tables that seemed to have enjoyed the treats.Overall, we had an outstanding experience! If you're looking for a more formal dinner with friends/family in Montreal that's on the pricier side but is still justified in its expenses, this is the place for you!

Our dinner last night, a cold, rainy evening, was excellent in all respects. The restaurant is so French it makes you believe you are sitting in Paris. The limited menu offers something for everyone. It being Good Friday, we sacrificed and chose the lobster stew and Dover sole. However, we did pass on desert, but avoided temptation by refusing to look at the desert menu. We had excellent martinis and a nice bottle of French Chardonnay. The wine list is primarily French, but includes bottles from all major wine producing countries. Service was outstanding and perfectly paced. The only possible improvement would be to add poutine to the menu!

Dropped in on a quiet chilly night recently. Started my meal with the onion soup. It was not presented in the same manner as the "French onion soup" I have enjoyed at other spots however the broth was  quite flavourful and it did take the chill off.For the main I had the fillet mignon. It was cooked perfectly and the peppercorn sauce was delicious.Finished the meal with the calvados soufflé. Despite its size, it was quite light.Room is very pleasant with a nice fireplace. The service was properly attentive without being overbearing.Price was reasonable considering the quality of the meal.

Hubba Hubba!!! When I dig into my memory bank and recall Restaurant Bonaparte, two things comes to mind. The Sirloin Steak. Never, Have I Ever, had a sirloin steak cooked to such perfection. Typically sirloin is not my go-to cut of steak but alas, Bonaparte showcases the sirloin like never before. Juicy and tender everything you want in a bite of steak is achieved!! Seasoned to perfection. AND we can not fail to mention the mushroom ravioli, I have a soft spot for pasta, the kind that is fresher than fresh and melts in your mouth. This mushroom ravioli would fool any Italian! Honorable mention goes to the sole which was also executed fantastically, but I'm personally not a huge fish eater.Great food is to be enjoyed at Bonaparte, the service is attentive and a visit during Restaurant Week did not disappoint us! It was a great way to try Bonaparte!

Came here for the first time for MTL à table. This place has amazing ratings online so my expectations were really high. The food was good, but not great. Everything lacked a bit of flavor and tasted a bit plain. Nothing was impressive and made me want to go back. On the other hand, the service was impeccable. We were served by friendly and nice staff who make great recommendations. They always have a smile on their face and came by our table a few times to make sure everything was ok. The restaurant itself has a nice quiet ambiance and is clean. It was a nice experience and we got to try a new restaurant. However, I don't think I would go back as it's not the kind of food that makes you suddenly have a craving for.

I will say that this place would be considered a little more high class.. everyone seemed to be more dressed up even for lunch... serves was a bit on the slowly side, but they only had 3 servers... also waited a long time for our food.. food comes in small portions, so we ordered an app and then entree. Overall the food was good, nothing disappointing..I didn't get a picture, but the provencale style tartlet of snail Friscassee was A M A Z I N G!

I had breakfast here.Stayed at the hotel which was very nice. Not the Hilton, more laid back vibe. The restaurant is a different matter.I just came in for the last out of 3 of my daily included breakfasts. I would have come in for all 3 had I known the meal. Waitstaff is professional and quiet. Limited breakfast menu but when my food arrived it was lovely. Excellent presentation, tasty, well plated. Small portions it seemed, but I was quite happy by the end of breakfast. Perfect scrambled eggs in a puff pastry, bacon rashers, toast, and a sausage. Orange juice, coffee, yogurt, fruit salad. A complete breakfast.Enter through the hotel lobby, pleasant bar, small but elegant dining room. Tall ceilings, large windows to the cobblestone street view. Old Montreal and a very cozy, elegant spot.Again: I was just there for breakfast. But I will go back for dinner.

We stayed in an airbnb property in the Old Port and chose this lovely restaurant just 2 blocks from our apartment--so glad we did! Wonderful menu which appeals to any preference--the Dover Sole and Beef Filet were exceptionally good. My husband swears he hates squash but the squash puree with orange which came with his filet was in his words, 'superb'. Everything we ordered was perfectly seasoned and delicious--its always wonderful to enjoy dishes like soup and cognac sauce which include classic and well-executed stock. We especially appreciated the dessert sampler which was just perfect for the 4 of us to share. Our waiter was personable and had the perfect recommendations. Best Cosmopolitans we've had in years---HIGHLY recommend.

What an amazing and pleasant experience!It was my birthday so my wife reserved ahead... But she made an error to reserve the restaurant at 7:45AM instead of 7:45PM LoL!!! The manager was very kind and offered us a table despite being on busy Friday night!We ordered the table d'hôte - great varieties of choices Btw! It's a 6 courses meal, soup/ 2 entrées/ sorbet to clean our tongue/ main course/ dessert, coffee or tea.Lobster soup, shrimp and scallop, foie gras crème brûlée, smoked salmon salad, filer mignon, duck breast are the one we chose from the menu and it was yummmmmy!We enjoyed every single dishes, everything were very top norch.Service wise, please ask for Jason! He will take care of you. It's been awhile that I've received such A++ service from waiters. He did an incredible job.I think their price is just right, not over priced at all. I really got a perfect meal, service and overall experience.Not only I will go back, I'll also recommend my friends!!!

Solid meal, and actually not as pricy as I anticipated.Atmosphere: Fancy, proper, clean. Spacious. I was scared I wasn't dressed fancy enough but people were in there with jeans and bags and everything, so they won't turn you away at least, haha.Food: Ordered a la carte. For starters, got the provencale style tartlet with parsley flavoured snails. Quite delightful! The snails had a good texture, and were heavily flavoured with what almost tasted like pesto. They were complimented by a yummy layer of puff pastry and the small salad-like accompaniment was delicious and tangy and tart. For my main, I ordered the Roasted duck breast flavored with maple syrup and wild berries. It was filling, the meat was tender, and the dish was very, very sweet. My partner ordered the Seafood and dish linguini with lobster sauce, and that was amazing. It looks like a little dish but it is packed with seafood and flavor. For dessert, we ordered the grand marnier souffle. I must admit, this tasted TOO much like gran marnier. If you don't want your dessert to taste like straight up alcohol, don't get this. Service: Quick, friendly, attentive.Overall, good dining experience and would recommend.

I always come to visit this restaurant when I'm in Montreal. Moderately priced for delicious food. My favourite is the foie gras creme brûlée and the mushroom ravioli. I've had each dish at least 3 times already! The $85 tasting menu is well worth the price, but come hungry because you'll be stuffed at the end. I recommend this restaurant to all my friends who visit Montreal.

I wish I could have enjoyed this place more. We made a reservation here for our first year wedding anniversary dinner. The reviews made the place sound amazing. We got there at 9pm and the waiter seemed a little cold and impatient. Fine. I read that the waiters are French and beautiful, so sure maybe they can be cold. However, I noticed that he was really warm to this other party of older couples. He was joking with them and everything. Then these other tables got brought celebratory candles and cake for their anniversaries from other waiters. We got nothing. Not even a congratulations. And yes I did mention this when booking the reservation that we were celebrating a special occasion. I don't expect restaurants to care or bring us anything or even say anything but it does hurt when other people get something special and we get neglected. We ordered a bottle of wine and I think the waiter was looking down on us because we wanted a full body but then didn't want to shell out 70$ for what he recommended. Oh well. On to the food, it was average. Small portions for the tasting menu. We got soup, smoked salmon, foies gras, scallops, and ravioli for the starters. The scallops and ravioli were delicious. Pear sorbet for palate cleanser before the main dishes. I got the fish which was refreshing and hubby got the duck breast which was good. Both entrees were yummy but nothing memorable. Dessert was some small cakes and creme brulee which was also good but not memorable. Expensive meal - around 250$ for mediocre. While meal ended at 12am. Service was really really slow!

Looking for a restaurant for 10 people that has tablecloths and doesn't break the bank was incredibly difficult. There aren't too many options that fit that description. Luckily, Bonaparte was able to accommodate our group, and it was a really nice meal. For 42 $CAN, the prix fixe is a great deal. I really liked my meal, though I wouldn't say any of the food really blew me away. I had the terrine, which was nice with the bread at the table, and the monkfish, which had a great lobster-meat texture and rich sauce. I snagged a bite of the meat tortellini, which was nice, and the lamb with pork belly was very decadent and well cooked.A friend had called in birthday desserts for the table, which was a nice touch. In retrospect, though, we realize with our prix fixe, we had already in essence paid for desserts. However, given the a la carte menu prices, we still made out with a bargain. It was nice for our big group to have a table in the corner so we could hear each other pretty well.
We were welcome for lunch by the charming and gracious maitre D. Food was of the highest standard and did not disappoint. Service was excellent. Hope to come back for dinner one day!

Excellent service, fantastic food. My partner and I were strolling through empty streets of Vieux Montreal on a rainy evening, and we were welcomed to Bonaparte next to a fireplace with excellent service and quiet ambiance.

You will begin by being courteously greeted by the host. A gentleman with very good taste in attire and who possesses fine manners. After being seated an explanation if the dishes is underway. Thorough wine pairing suggestions also follows. The food was absolutely delicious and you're treated like a king/queen. They have their dining etiquette down as a chic restaurant should have. A must try.

This restaurant is amazing! My husband and I started with the smoke salmon to share and they were nice enough divide the dish into 2 plates each looking very beautiful. My main was the duck and it was cooked to perfection! My husband had the tenderloin and really enjoyed it too. Their dessert menu is also fantastic and alot cheaper than other restaurants. We tried the Lemon tart and the was yummy. I think this will be a restaurant we will visit every time we are in town. I need to try their souffle and their french onion soup next time. I saw other customers have it and it looked really good. Make sure you come hungry so you can really enjoy their food. Reservations are easy to make by open table which is so convenient and it's in the heart of Old Montreal.

Great place, excellent food & lovely service, what more can you ask for! It's an upscale place but still not too pricey as compared to other places. My husband & I ordered the $42 three-course meal and it was great. He got a vegetable soup & I got a mixed greens salad with apple & oatmeal. Totally loved the salad, so fresh & light! His soup was ok too but I preferred the salad. Next, we both got chicken breasts, which the lovely waitress offered to serve with their sage cream sauce instead of the original maple syrup on the menu. The sauce was sooo good, I'm still salivating thinking about it Last, I got creme caramel while the husband got chocolate mousse. Totally loved the creme caramel, so delicious. Everything was perfect, including my Rose' wine. Will definitely visit this place again!

Had an incredible meal here with my sister on our last night in Montreal! We chose to do the tasting menu and were not disappointed. We both had the lobster bisque to start, creamy with pure lobster flavor. Then I had the warm goat cheese and my sister had the house smoke salmon, both incredible! Even someone who doesn't like the tartness of goat cheese would like it. Next course I had the mushroom ravioli, the pasta was so tender it melted in my mouth, perfect. My sister had the snails, garlicky buttery goodness! Next was a pear tarragon sorbet, light delicious and refreshing. For the main course I had the duck with maple syrup and berries, impeccably plated and delicious. My sister had the Dover sole, so tender and flaky! Dessert was an assortment, creme brûlée, maple cheesecake, raspberry bavarois and chocolate hazelnut mousse!! Ahhhhhhh soo good!

Excellent service. Be careful the sparkling water is $8 a bottle. It was good though. Knowing that the tasting menu can be quite a lot of food, we opted for the table d'hote which was appetizer, entrée, dessert and coffee or tea and a la carte of lobster bisque appetizer and duck breast entree.The lobster bisque was amazing, flavourful and fresh. The venison terrine was outstanding; the pickled vegetables were perfectly complimentary to the savory meat. Duck breast entree was lean and therefore best cooked to medium rare. Very delicious. The lamb shank entree was good, but it wasn't fall off the bone tender, the flavor was alright. The pork belly that came with it was also a bit tougher than I expected although it had good flavor. All the vegetables were delicious and cooked to their own degree of perfection. The lime pie dessert was to die for; great flavor and crust.  Paired with the strong coffee, it was a great way to end the evening. Highly recommended!

It is as lovely and delicious as the reviews say. We arrived in Montreal, checked into our hotel, freshened up, and walked to dinner.  We were warmly greeted and seated at our table. Our group of 6 had an array... Three people ordered from the prix fix - terrific selections and a great value. Three ordered a la carte.Started with champagne, then two lovely red wines. Dinner started with the foie gras, mushroom ravioli - both as good as the other reviews say. Others in our group had onion soup (bowl and grated cheese - not the heavy cheese out in a broiler type) so delish, soup (vegetable with ginger) and salad.  All apps were enthusiastically enjoyed. Main  meal included: rack of lamb cooked perfectly, veal chop (spectacular!), filet, and sole. All were great!  The service was wonderful. Couldn't have imagined a better way to start our vacation. (Thank you!)

I could've just said that it is a posh restaurant with unique delicious food and calm pleasant atmosphere, but it was too good to spare details.So I start with what was is bad:- Latte is served in a tall glass without a handle. Yes, it looks great and they give a towel to hold the glass, but I would prefer a simple cup.- Tea bag. C'mon guys, you have cotton towels in the restroom, and can't brew tea from normal leafs?That is pretty much everything I can complain about:- Onion soup was unusually tasty. I have tried it couple of times before and couldn't understand what's all the fuss about. Now I've finally ate a soup, not a mix of onions and salty water.- Mushroom ravioli were done right - not oversalted and without any aggressive sauce.- Duck with berries was quite a discovery- Deserts were perfect. I've ordered two :)Service consort the dishes: cloakroom attendant was quick and accurate, waiter recommended great wine to match our ducks, all the courses were served on time.

+.5 for serviceThis is the 4th French restaurant I tried in Montreal, and I do think it's the best one, at least out of the 4 I tried. I really like the ambience and setting of this restaurant, given the location in Old Montreal. It really does give the French-style dining feel that's quite common in these kinds of restaurants. There are three types of menus here: A la carte, table d'hote, and the tasting menu. Unlike many reviews here, I actually went with a la carte...not a fan of the whole tasting menu concept, and I do have an okay idea of what to expect for French cuisine.My family ordered the french onion soup, lobster bisque, smoked duck breast, escargots, vanilla flavoured shrimp, rack of lamb, and the veal chop. We finished off with a chocolate chip soufflé and a cheesecake.Where do I start...for the soups, the lobster bisque is definitely strong in the lobster fragrance category. I felt the taste was a bit light, but nothing too terrible about it. The french onion soup isn't the type with baked cheese on top, so do keep that in mind. I'd stick with the lobster bisque next time. Smoked duck breast, escargots, and vanilla flavoured shrimp were all uniquely presented and equally delicious. The rack of lamb was grilled perfectly, while the veal chop was a little bit more rare than what we requested (medium rare vs. medium).The desserts are a must here. Both the cheesecake and soufflé were some of the best I had; I definitely recommend the soufflé at the very least, even if it's a 15 minute wait.Service is excellent, all servers are bilingual. Of course, as common courtesy, do attempt to at least speak a bit of French.Will definitely recommend to my friends!

Alright but not great!Was really excited to see them on thrust of restaurants for Montreal a Table menu at $41.Started with the vegetable soup which was decent, not too salty. You can taste the ginger, tomato and carrots and probably some squash or pumpkin.Then followed by the creme brûlée au foie gras. I want to say that they chef did a horrible pairing with the bread. The cinnamon raisin bread definitely  overpowered and you can't taste the foie gras. I had to spread my foie gras on the table bread and it was much better. The texture was silky and the sugar coat added a nice texture and taste to the foie gras.Took the magret de canard with maple syrup and wild fruit sauce. I have to say that the duck was cooked perfectly...medium rare. However, the sauce was lacking substance...almost not enough flavour.Dessert was a combination of small pieces of cakes and creme brûlée...alright but not mind blowing.I'm really disappointed from this first experience given the good reviews on Yelp!
Can't say enough of this restaurant. Staff were just super friendly and informative, great food of course!

I have Practically no experience enjoying French food in a proper French restaurant in the past, this was the first one.   If I have the option to give 10 stars here I would rate 10 Without hesitation.    Very Nice food, Very good wine recommanded, Very good dessert.....and Most of all, Very good price!  I told the Lady who served us that I had fallen in love with French food right after my visit to them.   Really worth a visit if happen to be in Montreal.   Not a big restaurant but good enough, a little tight and cramp.   Very frienldly servers....all of them! Very prompt service, cozy ambient.....just one senior gentleman Who was celebrating something with his Friends talked a little Too loud, otherwise it was an unforgettable dining experience.

There is absolutely nothing wrong with this place. Everything is executed to perfection, however it felt like French dining at Epcot Center in Disney. There was no real passion that came through. It felt like a place designed to introduce people to French food. No complaints, but no fire.

We've spent the weekend in Montreal, and I really wanted to try a well regarded French restaurant while we are here.  I narrowed it down to Bonaparte and Montreal Plaza, we ended up going to the former because we were staying near Old Montreal.  We decided to try the tasting menu as it contained most of the dishes we wanted to try and the price was relatively reasonable for a 6 course menu (CAD 78).  See below for the dishes we tried:Lobster bisque enhanced with Ginger - my guy really liked this dish, I thought it was too creamy, but it was flavorfulSalad of mixed greens with pine nuts and parmesan cheese - I actually loved this dish, as weird as it might sound.  It was a simple salad dish, but I loved the different type of greens and how well they complimented each other.  Also, I appreciate how lightly they dressed the salad, as some places tend to get heavy-handed with the dressing.  It goes to show a delicious tasting dish does not need to be complicated.Duck foie gras crème brulée, sautéed apples - we were mixed on this dish.  I loved it, he didn't.  I am a huge fan of foie gras, and the technique of brulee-ing anything.  Who doesn't love the crackle of caramelized sugar?  I wasn't crazy about the cake-y type of bread that accompanied the dish, but the foie gras went well with the bread basket.Shrimp and scallop harmony flavoured with vanilla - I thought this dish was just ok, it came with two pieces of shrimp and a piece of scallop.  I thought the shrimps were a tad overcooked.Mushroom raviolis perfumed with fresh sage - my favorite dish of the evening.  The sage provided a wonderful flavor that pushed the dish from good to great.  I loved how well the raviolis were cooked and the sauce had the perfect amount of creaminess.Pear and tarragon sorbet - I could eat a whole tub of the sorbet, it was light yet flavorful.  It was definitely a great palate cleanserDuck breast flavoured with maple syrup and wild berries - I thought the duck was well flavored and perfectly medium rare, just like I asked for.  Roasted rack of lamb and port wine 'jus' - I normally love lamb, but was not a big fan of this one.  The flavor was lacking.  I thought it was interesting that they give you the same vegetables for all of the main courses.Homemade Desserts - they had a trio of cakes (chocolate mousse, raspberry and cheesecake), as well as creme brulee.  The only standout was the cheesecake, which was heavenly, if I had room, I would've ordered a whole slice of it.I hate to say it, but the service was lackluster for this caliber of restaurant.  I had to track down the waiter a few times just to refill my water glass, yet he was pretty fast in offering me another glass of wine.  Also, I really wanted coffee with my dessert, but had to track down someone again to inquire about the coffee after I've already finished my dessert.  To be fair, it was a packed dining room the night I was there, but I have a different expectation for a formal sit down place like this one.  Overall, I think it was a great experience, I've enjoyed most of the dishes in the tasting menu, and it was definitely worth it to try it once.  I definitely recommend it if you are in town.

Went there with the boyfriend for Valentine's day. I am giving 3 stars about this specific day with a fixed menu. We had a 5 course meal and I loved half of the items and the other half was just ok. The soup was ok, the goat cheese pastries were good and charcuterie plate was just ok but I'm not a big fan of this. The main plate was incredible!! Meat was so tender and juicy, it was melting in my mouth. The dessert (usually my favourite part) was kinda average small pastries some were dry and other very good. Service was excellent and friendly.

This restaurant deserves the 5 stars, especially if you're staying at the auberge (hotel Bonaparte), as you'll enjoy the breakfast and excellent service they provide.  The tasting menu was magnifique!

I had a great time here. The entrance for this restaurant is through the hotels lobby. The beer selection at the bar was okay with their typical Canadian beer. Anyway, we were here for tasting menu and some wine. Our waitress was really attentive. She recommended us some good white wine to go with out tasting menu. It was a 6-course tasting menu. We first started with a lobster bisque. It was pretty good. Then came the foie gras crème brûlée was alright with the easy-to-crumble bread. The third course which were escargots was to die for. The there was an intermission with sorbet. It was very refreshing and good for cleansing your palate for my next entrée which was a medium rare rack of lamb. Omfg, you need to get this! We ended the dinner with another Crème Brûlée and some cheese cake. Overall, it was a great tasting menu. We spent three hours there with three bottle of white wine.We will be back again for sure!PS your wifi did not work!

On a visit to Montreal, and an anniversary dinner, we had the pleasure of dining at Restaurant Bonaparte. And, most enjoyably, being graciously guided through the evening by Katherine.From the first to last bite, the food and service were world class. The wine list, by the glass, bottle or half-bottle, expertly assembled for all tastes. The decor was elegant, yet relaxed, we felt welcomed upon entering, and truly look forward to returning again and again.

A great fine dining experience in Old Montréal. The service was professional and fun, enhancing the meal and helping to make decisions about the menu when asked.  We had the three-course fixed menu and we couldn't have been happier with our selections. They also offer a seven course tasting menu. Highly recommended!

The weather was warm this Christmas, making a trip to Old Montreal a pleasure. It was too dark for window shopping but we were able to enjoy the many Christmas decorations and lights that adorned cafes and tourist venues.Bonaparte is a quaint and charming restaurant adjoining an auberge. We were seated by the window, in an intimate room with rough brick walls, a curved archway, and a lovely, decorated tree.As we reviewed the large menu, we took in the street life, including romantic calèche rides that rolled slowly by. While I could not make out the drivers' patter, I would like to imagine tales of adventure and romance. It is Montreal, of course.The restaurant offers several different dining options: à la carte, table d'hôte, and tasting menu. We did not have the energy for the longer tasting menu option and instead went with the à la carte option.We shared the mushroom and sage ravioli. The filling was wrapped in a delicately thin pasta that melted with every bite. It is a wonderful way to start the meal. Other apps on the menu include snails in garlic sauce, shrimps and scallops in a cheese sauce, and foie gras, two ways.As entrée, I enjoyed duck breast roasted medium rare, with vegetables, in a savory maple syrup, berry sauce. So delicious.However, it was the soufflé dessert that earned the most praise at our table. Available with chocolate crumbs, calvados brandy (the chef's favorite), and Grand Marnier, the impossibly light and airy soufflé was a welcomed treat. Note, since it takes a while to prepare, the restaurant recommended that we order it mid-entree - which we did.Service was warm and professional. The server made good recommendations, although I think there isn't a bad meal to be had here. With such an extensive menu, we think that a subsequent visit is definitely in order. With the soufflé, of course.

Excellent French cuisine in old Montreal. Very elegant and classy atmosphere with excellent service from the staff and tasty food. I ordered the foie gras as an appetizer and lamb as my entree. You can literally feel the love poured into every dish by the chef and I was very impressed. Also, a plus is there's some good looking workers at the restaurant. ;)

I was lucky enough to be in Montreal during the week of MTLatable, and upon recommendation from my friend, we decided to try this restaurant for my first dinner here. Restaurant Bonaparte is located within hotel Bonaparte in old Montreal... a very walkable distance from where I was staying, and features some delicious French cuisine.  I really enjoyed my experience here!Atmosphere: 4.5/5  Great ambience, soft lighting, and great decor with stone walls.  Very classy setting to enjoy a great mealFood: 4.5/5  We ended up choosing from the MTLatable set menu.  I had the salad to start, homemade game terrine, duck breast with maple syrup and berries, and lemon meringue pie for dessert.  Everything was delicious!  It was my first time having game terrine, which was an interesting experience but I liked the texture.  The duck breast was cooked well, and I especially liked the sweet freshness from the berries, which went well w the meat.  The lemon meringue pie was delicious as well - I normally don't like too much cream but this was not too heavy or sweet.  Overall great experience - only thing was the bread was not warm but everything else made up for it!Service: 4.5/5 Great service; attentive and friendly without being overbearing; good explanation of menuPrice: 3.5/5  Overall $41 for delicious cuisine and excellent service in a great environment - I would say this is extremely reasonableOverall: 4.5/5  I loved my experience at bonaparte restaurant - great atmosphere to enjoy a meal while catching up with my friend; I would definitely recommend this restaurant to visitors!

Some of the Yelp reviews mentioned lackluster service, so I had low expectations coming here. However, the waitstaff was very attentive - no problem whatsoever!Now on to the food. The $78 tasting menu is a good deal. Go for it!As many have already said, the creme brûlée style foie gras is imaginative. However, like others, I can't understand why they chose to pair it with cake-y bread. It's like a bad VP running mate (think Sarah Palin). Why? Just why?!The mushroom ravioli dish tasted super buttery - not a bad thing in my book. The duck was a little tougher than medium rare calls for, but tasty nonetheless.They went overboard with the dessert. No one needs chocolate cake, raspberry cake, cheese cake, AND creme brûlée all at the same time, however small the portions. Two would've been perfect.The ambience was average, neither too casual nor too formal or romantic. Overall, a solid choice.
This is probably is the best of the best coming from SF we have the best choices but this place is above and beyond food amazing service super

My boyfriend decided to take me here for my birthday, because we had a very good experience with another french restaurand and adored it! And so we did! The food was delicious and fresh, and the service impecable! Beautiful restaurant and deliciousssssssss drinks! Definetely recommend!

We were able to get a last minute reservation on a Friday night. My husband and I opted for the 6 course (per person) meal and we each ordered something different. This gave us the opportunity to try 12 different things including the "symphony of desserts" which allowed us to taste a little of everything. This was hands down the best meal we've ever had anywhere. Everything we ordered was amazing and the service was impeccable.

Nicest people serving you. Great bartenders. They make an old fashioned using maple syrup and a combination of bitters including fig/cinnamon. Fantastic! Food was hit or miss. Mushroom tortellini was delicious. I then ordered lamb shank/pork belly combo. Strange combination but I don't cook a lot of meat for myself so indulge when I eat out. The lamb shank was tender and tasty. The pork belly dried out and tasteless. Dessert was a flan that I thought was good, but nothing spectacular. Good value, especially considering the state of the CAD conversion from USD.

Excellent experience overall. We ordered à la carte: onion soup and filet mignon for my companion, and goat cheese croustillant and lobster navarin for me. Everything was very good. Beautifully presented vegetable accompaniments: probably my favorite part of the entire meal was the parsnip/sweet potato side, which was beautifully seasoned. Note: the lobster navarin is translated as "stew," but it is not liquid-based. It is a delicious and generous portion of fresh lobster on a bit of pasta, with several small and delicious vegetable accompaniments. I told our server I almost didn't order it because I didn't want "soupe" and he said customers were sometimes confused by the word "stew." Funny they don't clarify it so more people order it.We quickly found a 1/2 liter wine to share, so we dId not scrutinize the wine list, but it was extensive.We shared the soufflé for dessert. We were too full and were not sure about  the soufflé flavors (calvados, grand marnier, and chocolate chip). I wished for chocolate. But how can you turn down a soufflé when someone else is making it? The chocolate chip was a nice surprise: the pockets of melted chocolate within the plain soufflé were great.A great after-dinner drinks list, we had port and Armagnac. Both very good.The decor is a bit staid. I wouldn't mind more character. But it's quiet and peaceful, so that one can enjoy the meal fully. They put a sparkler on my soufflé for my birthday.There are other places in the neighborhood that are more lively, cheaper, but still with fine food, with a younger crowd, noisier,  and so on. We also like Holder: if you are looking for something like that atmosphere and still really good food you might prefer it to Bonaparte.Above all, the service was excellent. Polite and professional, but also warm and ready to answer questions. None of the snoot  you get in high-end restaurants in, say, NYC. And the staff are clearly invested in their work.If you haven't splurged on a real fancy meal before, this is a good place to start. They'll welcome you and host you with care.Our meal was $260 for two, including one dessert, one 1/2 liter of wine , and two splurgy after-dinner drinks.  A starter and main were more than filling enough.

Our favorite restaurant in Montreal. Both food and service are exceptional!We selected the large 7 course meal.  Each course was the perfect size and the time between courses was just right.  Our waiter said we would feel satisfied at the end of the meal without feeling too full. He was right. Each course was was presented perfectly. I've included some of our selections.   If you are in or near old Montreal and are in search of a n exceptional meal this is the place.

This place is simply not worth the price. One of us had the tuna steak from the a la carte menu while the other had the prix fixe menu. The prix fixe was vegetable soup, steak and chocolate mousse. The food just isn't good. The steak is average at best, while the tuna tasted cheap and poorly prepared. The worst part is that both entrees - one prix fixe, the other a la carte, both came with the same exact sides (see images). Grilled vegetables and squash. Where is the creativity? Or even the simple acknowledgement that different entrees (meat vs fish) need different accompaniments? Ultimately feels like lazy, bad food for $45+ without even getting a drink. Cocktails on the menu, while not tried, looked very standard. Why even put an Old Fashioned that follows the basic recipe to a tee on the menu? Again, why pay a premium for basics?The service was the silver lining, which was fantastic. The waitstaff are attentive and hospitable. The decor is nice in the classic restaurant (read: not trendy) sense. Do better, support a harder working chef, get what you pay for. Go elsewhere.

Classical French cuisine. Located in the Hotel Bonaparte. A very charming restaurant where we sat in an alcove between the 2 main dining areas.I would give it  4  1/2 stars. Excellent wait staff and a talented French chef.Started with 'Provençale' style tartlet with parsley flavored snails, great, French onion soup, and vanilla flavored shrimp and scallop harmony and leek fondue, superb.For entrees, we had the roasted duck breast flavored with maple syrup and wild berries , amazing and a very good chicken breast served with melted brie and sage cream sauce .The grand finale, a superb, Chocolate chip soufflé.  They have a great wine list.Truly a very enjoyable evening and our best dining experience in Montreal.

Great food and very generous portion. The service was great. Was a great experience.Would have been better if they post the wine list on the website. It's doable to find decent wine with affordable price.

For a high end restaurant, I had high expectations. I had dinner here a year ago and was thoroughly impressed. However this year, staying at the hotel, we had several opportunities to stay here.With a nearly empty restaurant at breakfast, it will still take 15 minutes to sit 5 people and 40 minutes to get your breakfast and the server will almost never be around. At dinner, we ordered a bottle of wine, the server broke the cork, and pushed the broken piece down into the bottle. She did not offer to get us a new bottle, instead just poured it for us. We had broken pieces of cork we had to fish out of our wine glasses. For a $500 check, we expected we could at least get a fresh bottle of wine.That being said, the restrooms were exquisite and the kitchen did an absolutely wonderful job. It's just the service that needs improvement.
bon appétitYummy! The best beef tartare I have ever had and the beef mignon is tender. The server qualities are professional and a must visit stop for French cuisine when visiting Montréal.
Terrific food - professional, caring, meticulous excellent service- warm, classic French ambience-beyond expectations - whole heartedly recommend

The Restaurant Bonaparte is our favorite dining in all of Montreal.   From a very skilled craftsmen behind the bar creating vintage cocktails to the Michelin quality chef this dining experience did not disappoint.   We dined several nights here and each night the food was fantastic.   And the service is on par with everything else!!
Had dinner here for my bachelorette party. The atmosphere is fancy and every staff member will greet you which I liked. The food was good and very timely, prices fair. Overall good experience.

Do not get exiled to the back room! Bonaparte is our once (or twice) a year treat so we were very disappointed with our Christmas Eve dinner, which was not up to the restaurant's usual standards.  We were seated in the back room (8 tables) and service was incredibly slow.  We waited to receive menus, waited for water, waited for our drinks, and after about 30 minutes the waiter finally took our order.  By that time I had almost forgotten what I wanted.  This treatment was not unique to our table.  Every table I could see sat for a long time with their menus closed while the waiter walked past them multiple times.  The family of four next to us also waited about 30 minutes to order, although at least they got bread while they were waiting.  For some reason, the server (assistant waiter?) didn't give us bread until we had ordered (did he think we would eat it and leave?).Thankfully we only ordered the three course meal, because it took as long to arrive as the five course tasting menu.  Please note that I wrote "arrive" because it did not take us 3+ hours to eat our food, we were just waiting - often with empty dirty plates in front of us and empty glasses.Overall the food was good, but not what we expect from Bonaparte.  My husband was not happy that his mushroom ravioli were stuck to the plate, probably because the dish had been sitting under the hot lamp in the kitchen for so long.  This supported our theory that the problem was with the service, not with the kitchen.We would have asked for a fresh dish, but the waiter and server were rarely there.  Each would do one task and then leave the room.  We weren't the only frustrated table.  Something was wrong with a dish at the table next to us and he fumed for probably 5 minutes waiting to see someone to complain to.I think the problem was our location.  In the past, I've seen the maître d' take orders, remove empty dishes, etc.  But there was no one walking through our room to see that our waiter and server were unable to do these basic tasks in a reasonable amount of time.Will we go back?  Maybe.  But probably not on a holiday.  And if they try to seat us in the back again, we will wait for a different table.

Ever have that experience that makes you reassess the things that impressed you in the past? Dining at Bonaparte was such an experience! Reception was excellent!Coat Check Excellent!The bar was really cool, and our bartender was attentive and engaging.The Maitre D'hotel was Exceptional!Our meal was Outstanding!Onion soup and Lobster Bisque were off the charts.Our waiter was great!It will not disappoint

Very good French restaurant. It's been my third time here and I'm not getting disappointed. The dishes are amazing and tasty. The waitress was awesome and they set us on a very romantic spot. We got the tasting menu and we felt full and the end of the dinner. I recommend this place!
Venison medallion with mushroom ravioli was added to their 34 year old menu so I had to give it a try.  Wow...and wow.  Delicious!
Beautiful restaurant, classic french dishes, my favorite was the mushroom ravioli (I could have had two of them!) the bar is cute and nice wine selection.

Excellent service and really good food. I got the duck and my husband had filet both were above average. The best part of the night was the snail appetizer. If i was local, I would certainly come back to this place.

Simply awesome.  Workers....amazingService...amazingFood....amazingI had the mushroom raviolis and filet for dinner.  FantasticIf you are in Montreal traveling and want a nice French meal, go here. Great wine selection as well.

This was one of the finest dining experiences we've ever had. Both my wife and I had the degustation menu, 6 courses, with enough choices to satisfy both a seafood lover (me) and a non-seafood lover (wife). Every course was exceptional; from the description on the menu, to the presentation, to the taste. The service was top-notch, and the spacing of each course's delivery was perfect. If you are near Old Town Montreal, do yourself a favor and go to Bonaparte.

Bonaparte is by far our favorite restaurant we have been to since we have been together! To start, the staff is wonderful! They are absolutely lovely, attentive, knowledgeable, polite, and friendly.The good is outstanding. We started with the lobster bisque and the escargot. Wow! Delightful!The main course... I can't stop talking about it! The lobster linguini was just incredible. I thought I was getting bits of lobster with a full plate of linguini... was I wrong!  I had a full lobster with a small side of linguini and vegetables! We can't say enough about this restaurant! It is an absolute must if you visit Old Montreal!

Enjoyed a delicious dinner with exceptional service. All four of us were genuinely impressed. Good atmosphere with warm friendly service that wasn't over the top. Just right. Recommend for wonderful French Canadian fare menu which is exactly what we were looking for.

Decor: nice and cozy. A bit dark with a beautiful flower on the table. I would not classify the place as casual and was happy I wore a dress to go there. The restaurant is decorated in a Classic French style and we got lucky to get a spot by a window facing a small stone paved street.Service: people working there take their jobs seriously. They were all men, all dressed to impress and ALL good looking. My boyfriend made a comment to me after a few waiters stopped by asking: "are they all models here?"Food: the food was good. I must say that we got spoiled on our first night in Montreal because we dined in one of the top restaurants which was hard to match after.  The food here provided classic options that were well executed and presented. The soup was great and I liked the take on the smoked salmon. I was especially a fan of the  seafood main course. We had a big selection of courses from a pre-fix menu in a classy atmosphere and at a fair value. Can't beat that...

user_city: West Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, CA
user_review: This is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the world. Even their water tastes so good. They gave us the best table at the restaurant even tho we were incredibly early. And the food was amazing. I wish we had the 8 course meal to try out as many dishes as possible. This is worth every penny. Also there was an issue with a busser but when I emailed them about it after the trip they were quick to apologize and addressed the issue. I want to come back to Montreal just to eat at this restaurant. Highly recommend.
Everything was prefect, from the duck breast to desserts. Service was exceptional, extremely professional and warm.

Fantastic atmosphere, food , drinks and service.  Bonaparte came highly recommended and did not disappoint.Reservation recommended and was easy to do online.Maximas behind the bar made great cosmo and whiskey sour.  He was entertaining as well.We splurged on the 6 course menu and  Loved every course.    Our server was first rate and professional We will be back

Absolutely phenomenal. One of the best eating experiences I've ever had. The food was spectacularly good. I've been to Chef Yannick Alleno's restaurant Pavillion Alleno in Paris. I honestly rank the quality of the food at Bonaparte to be right up there with Alleno. Obviously more traditional fare at Bonaparte, but nonetheless excellent.

Loved this place! Came to Montreal for a visit and tried a bunch of places in my short stay but this is by far my favorite. The ambiance is romantic but not too quiet. The food is delicious. A little pricy but not too bad when converted to American dollars. I got the lobster bisque which is AMAZING! And the duck as my main course and it was FANTASTIC. My friends loved their onion soups and the goat cheese appetizer (which I tried and I conquer!). The dessert is good. I'd definitely skip the soufflé it was way too eggy. But then again I was never a fan of soufflé. The cheese cake and chocolate cake were delicious though. I highly recommend this place.

This is a great place for a night out. Make sure you reserve ahead online ( I did it via OpenTable).The ambience is great, noise level is just right. The environment is semi-formal ish (just a dress shit for guys would do it).The tasting menu is great; good amount of food and great selections. The service was also excellent. Overall a great dining experience.

We had the $78 tasting menu with the rack of lamb as the main, while my wife chose the prix fixe with the steak. Tasting menu portions were much larger than I expected, so there was certainly good value for the price while dessert was a struggle to finish. The hits were the shrimp and scallop in vanilla, the mushroom ravioli and the lamb. The rest, lobster bisque, foie gras creme brûlée and dessert were fine. Service was great (it was a weeknight, quite late, and a big party), and in particular they were very patient in letting us close the place down.
Came here for my birthday. Great service and I really enjoyed the ambiance. The food was well cooked and came out fast even though the restaurant was filled. Enjoyed the fra gras.
Fine dining experience all around.  The food and service were exceptional. One dish after another.....  just perfect.

Wonderful service, we had no reservations but we got seated right away nonetheless. We ordered the multiple course meal and were not disappointed. The lobster bisque was creamy and full bodied. We had the warm goat cheese in phyllo dough, it was creamy, tart, and buttery crisp. The escargot was the perfect texture and the contrast of the soft escargot and the phyllo shell was highly enjoyable. The duck was tender and sweet, the tartness of the berries didn't let the maple flavor overpower the dish. As for dessert, although the sampling was quite enjoyable, the creme brûlée was the star, the sugar was caramelized just right, and the custard itself was smooth and creamy, sweet, yet light. It was the best meal ever and I'm so happy we splurged.

Service was wonderful, but a little slow to the table. Food did come out promptly though. Tasting menu was well balanced and offered a great selection. Wine selection was diverse and paired wonderfully with the meal. Environment/setting was perfect as well. Price point was very fair.
My favorite restaurant in Montreal.  Nice ambiance and stellar service besides their exquisite dishes.

Fantastically French. We went here for our usual "one really nice dinner while we're here" and Bonaparte did not disappoint! We scarfed down the bread and butter and our cocktails like disgusting heathens and loved every second of it. Our wait staff was fantastic in both English and French, and having spent some time in France, Bonaparte is, so far, the closest resemblance to a great French Restaurant I've been to since. My only criticism for this restaurant, and this is a common trend, is that the beer selection could be vastly improved for a restaurant of this caliber. Now, as a French restaurant it's all about the wine, and my Graham's desert wine (my favorite) did not disappoint, but it would be nice to see more attention paid to the beer selection just to make sure the restaurant is firing on absolutely all cylinders.If you're a vegetarian, please keep in mind that the menu is quite limited. I don't allow this fact to influence my reviews, as I don't try to impose my diet on others, but this is something to consider (maybe have a snack beforehand). I enjoyed the mushroom ravioli from the starters menu, and then really delved into the soufflé and  crème brûlée. The soufflé was crazy. Make a reservation.

We dined at Restaurant Bonaparte for a birthday, and everything was fantastic! The place does seem like it caters to a more conservative, older crowd, but the menu is varied and everything looked very appetizing.  Right off the bat I noticed they had a snail entrée, I'm a fan! It was absolutely delicious, and the portion size was perfect. They do try to incorporate vegetarian options (well...one option) and it does feel like an afterthought a bit, but since I didn't order it, I can't say too much. Instead I opted for the magret de canard served with a berry sauce and a squash purée and ...honestly I have nothing bad to say. We wanted to finish on a high note and ordered dessert. I liked my lime pie, but I would have liked it more if there was more of it. The Grand Marnier soufflé is not only massive, but very boozy. Very. Boozy. They have a massive - and expensive - sampling menu that I keep in the back of my mind..

Wow, Orgasmic!!! One of the Best French restaurant in Montreal. The service is impressive. The staff makes sure that all your needs are met. I started out with a warm goat cheese in a Phyllo with almonds. Was light and tasty. As the main meal I had the Baby Calf liver served in a Porto sauce, this was cooked to perfection Moist and Tender. Yes it's an expensive place to eat but when the food is delicious price does not matter. You leave feeling fully satisfied... what better feeling than that!! ;))

We had a really nice time for an anniversary dinner. We got the tasting menu and everything we had was delicious. Service was fantastic and atmosphere had a relaxed upscale vibe. Prior to our visit I was worried the restaurant would be for an older crowd or tired but it was not the case. The escargot and filet was my husbands favorite and I liked the goat cheese and dessert plate. We were impressed and would go back and recommend to others. The tasting menu is worth the price for a special occasion.

Simply magical!Walked in off the street, hoping for a chance to sit down, as this was on a Friday night, during the Montreal restaurant week with fixed price menus. Was told there are no seats, as we didn't have a reservation, however after a second the manager said that he may have a table for us, if we will take it. Expecting something in the crawl space above the attic or under the basement stairs, we were led to a cozy table by the fireplace. If you think this was amazing, then the food was triple amazing, the waiters were very nice and nearly invisible yet always there when you needed them, and happy to provide advice on food pairings and etc. The place is not cheap, but worth every penny. A definite repeat.

What a treat! Go here if you are looking for an intimate,beautiful Restuarant with fantastic food. With a pre-fixed menu,  for $41 you can get an appetizer, dinner & desert. There are a ton of options with a quite extensive and lavish food and wine list. My favorite part was the peppercorn steak which was cooked perfectly. Wait staff was extremely friendly and attentive. Can't wait to go back!  Pictured is my delicious dessert (key lime/lemon meringue pie and tea) included in the pre-fixed menu.
Excellent meal, great service, lovely restaurant and so close to our hotel. Wonderful way to end our vacation.
Walking by and saw this restaurant and decided to give it a try.  It's very cute and the setting is cozy. Food is excellent and this is what I expect French restaurant the standard should be.

A great place for a celebration. The service was absolutely phenomenal and the food was very interesting with the kitchen trying some interesting combinations like the lobster stew with vanilla. An adventurous risk with maybe just a dash too much vanilla but delicious nonetheless. The wine is fantastic here but on the pricier end. The food also could have been hotter, not sure who to blame for that. Overall expect to spend about $100 per person with wine for a three course meal. I would say it's worth the money for a special occasion.

Fabulous food, not disappointed! Did not give a 5 star....be prepared to include a long waiting time for food to arrive... however when it arrives, it is as good as it can get! Took my son for graduation trip to Quebec, as this was as good as in France! Close your eyes and your transported!

The restaurant was over priced and the food was only mediocre.  I had ordered the fish for dinner and it was extremely bland.  My son ordered the hanger steak and it was over cooked.  The service was excellent and the wait staff extremely attentive.  I wouldn't recommend eating here.

If you are looking for a really high class French Restaurant, without leaving N. America... this is the place.Service was outstanding. Our waiter was from Paris, living in Montreal.Appetizers: Rabbit Confit & Wild game terrine.... amazing!! Entree: Hanger steak with a Cognac & peppercorn sauce.Dessert: Flan & Chocolate mousse.The flavors of these foods was exquisite!We have been to restaurants all over the US and Europe... this is one of the best meals we've ever had!AWESOME!!

Bonaparte is one of the classiest, ritziest, most fantastical restaurants I have ever been to. The food, the atmosphere, and the service are fantastic. You will pay for it, but it is an experience and worth it. The Dover entree is amazing and easily top 5 fish dish I have ever eaten. Foie gras creme brûlée is fantastic and I am almost sure everything served at Bonaparte is as well. The menu can be a bit confusing but basically you can order a la carte or choose a 5 course tasting menu.

A lovely and beautiful place to enjoy food. A find In the old heart of the city. The food was elegantly served. The waitstaff was on pointe and charming. Dessert luscious I'd highly suggest a stop here.

Lunch. Service was outstanding without pressure. We had a 2 hour European style lunch. My porc tenderloin in a brown mustard sauce was perfect.  Wine list is extensive. Make this meal the event of the day, it was for us.

I went here to finish off my Montreal trip and it certainly finished with a bang at Bonaparte! I felt like I was enjoying authentic French cuisine in a high class environment. Mushroom ravioli, the duck, my friend's sirloin steak, and cheesecake are the things I had that I would say are worth the price of admission. Some people may consider it to be pricey but for what you get and comparing to restaurants of this calibre, it's worth it and right in line.Our service was prompt and on top of things. The waiter was even there to clean up the mess I had made with the pepper shaker.Overall, I would definitely recommend this place to people especially those looking to enjoy a fancy, classy dining experience and feel pampered.

Food: 4/5Service: 4/5Atmosphere: 4.5/5Cleanliness: 4.5/5Price: $$$$The words 'affordable' and 'tasting menu' don't really go together, but I think Restaurant Bonaparte in Old Montréal is one that fits the description! It's one of the highest rated restaurants for French cuisine in the city, and rightfully so. Hubby and I visited the restaurant last year, but I think our tasting menu experience is worth reading because the menu doesn't seem to have changed much on their website.I ordered a glass of white wine to have along with my tasting menu, though I don't remember which one I ordered.A complimentary bread was given also, filled with an assortment baguettes and other French breads. I decided to try their lobster bisque for my first course while my husband decided to try the salad. The soup was delicious, and I would've loved to order it separately on another occasion upon available. Portion sizes were also pretty good, not too small but not so large leaving me with no room for the next course.For our second course, I chose the duck foie gras creme brûlée while my husband chose the smoked salmon dish. Both were equally good, but I thought that my dish was more creative therefore more unique. I love trying unique dishes whenever I try a tasting menu; trying duck foie gras was unique to begin with because usually foie gras is from geese, not duck. To be honest, I couldn't tell a big difference, especially because it was made into a creme brûlée. I guess using duck foie gras kept the price of the tasting menu in check, bringing down the price overall and making it more affordable.Hubby's smoked salmon was great, but he preferred my dish over his. The truffle oil was a nice touch, but if you know truffle, you'd know that there isn't actually any truffle in truffle oil, just the scent. Anyway, it was still good nonetheless, especially with the smoked salmon, but we would prefer to order the duck foie gras creme brûlée over the smoked salmon if you eat foie gras.Our next course was nice, but to be honest not the most memorable. It was good - definitely not bad, but nothing particular really stood out to us in either of the dishes.Our fourth course was a breather, one where our palates were refreshed and reset for the upcoming main course. The sorbet was really light and  delicious! Though I haven't had much tarragon before, the herb was well balanced with the sweetness of the pear.The real highlight of the night was the rack of lamb presented for our fifth and main course. Hubby chose to have the beef filet mignon which was just as good, but the roasted rack of lamb that I had was so much better. The port wine 'jus' was so incredibly delicious! We highly recommend that you order the rack of lamb as well if you like lamb. The gamey smell of lamb is nonexistent and the meat was so tender and juicy. The portions of the lamb weren't too bad for a tasting meal either.To end off our tasting menu and date night, we were served an assortment of desserts for our last course. We were also offered some tea or coffee which we delightedly enjoyed. I always get peppermint tea whenever I can after a large meal which I think helps soothe me and my bloated stomach. The desserts weren't too creative but delicious nonetheless.If you're looking for a place to take your significant other on a romantic dinner, I highly recommend Bonaparte and their tasting menu! Though there are numerous romantic restaurants in Old Montreal, Bonaparte outdone themselves with the quality of their tasting menu while keeping the price tag relatively affordable for a tasting menu. A quick google search of Bonaparte gives you endless 5 star ratings of the restaurant, and for good reason! I would revisit Bonaparte in a heartbeat and order their tasting menu again because I enjoyed it that much.
This place is excellent! Amazing service and spectacular food! It's definitely on my list of places to go to when I'm in Montreal.

Amazing. One of the best (if not THE best) dining experience we've ever had. Food, wine, service....EVERYTHING. We are foodies who have lived in many cities, and traveled the world. We were blown away. We're not sad that we couldn't FIND Bouillon Bilk (there are no signs--a subtle f-you to tourists) and thus missed our reservation there. Happy accident! Do yourself a favor and make your reservations for this place!!!

Without a doubt, I have to say that this is one of the best hotels I've ever stayed at.  No hyperbole.  This was effing fantastic.When I got to the hotel, I was pretty exhausted from trying to navigate my way around the city to get there on public transit.  Walked in, and they greeted me warmly, checked me in fairly quickly, and gave me a glass of champagne to help me settle in.  I was floored (in a good way).The room itself was a fantastic blend of old and new - exposed brick, mixed with hardwood floors and a modern take on classic furniture.  Classy, simple, and tasteful - and at a price that was pretty sweet to boot.The room also came with a morning breakfast - and we're talking about a made to order selection here - all done in their restaurant, and all ridiculously good with a great choice of breads to go along with it.This isn't your typical Hilton or Marriott - this is some place really special.  And I can't wait to stay there again.

Had an excellent dinner on the evening of Sat 05/28/16. The lobster bisque was rich and delicious. Appetizers were Mushroom Ravioli and Fois Gras Creme Brulee. Both excellent.Sliced, Roasted Duck breast with a maple syrup-flavored sauce and Sesame-crusted Red Tuna entrees. Awesome. Chocolate Mousse and "assorted dessert plate" finished a very, very nice meal. Caroline was a delightful waitress. Attentive, but not overly-so and really helpful in recommending some wonderful wines to pair with our food (and within our budget parameters we conveyed). Great place.
This place is simply "fantastic", basically one of the best confit de canard I've ever eaten if not the best!!!  The service is also exceptional, a must go place if you are in Montreal...

I came here with my girlfriends as I had my bachelorette dinner here. They had a nice table for us set up in the corner. It was nice and dim and the food was good. We were able to make reservations to sit a fairly large group. It was definitely a nice restaurant.

My husband and I dined at Bonaparte for our Anniversary and it was simply amazing!!  The food was great, the ambience was calm and romantic and the service was top-notch!  You won't regret going here.

Good restaurant in Old Montreal.I should tell you Old Montreal is really torn up right now and the street Bonaparte is on is completely torn up .Don't even consider driving!Went here for what amounted to Thanksgiving dinner.We  had the Table D hote, which is reasonably priced.I had the venison terrine and beef filet , both of which were excellent.My wife had a soup - a cream of leek with another vegetable in it and haddock with lobster sauce.Unusually , because we were early , we had a cocktail  at the bar.I had something called an ephmerie  - maybe- which had a number of ingredients including elder flower liqueur and chartreuse, which was very good.Service was good  and it was a pleasnt evening.

After several years, we returned to Montreal and We planned to revisit this wonderful experience. I requested the concierge to reserve a table near the window of this upscale French restaurant overlooking the cobblestone street with horse carriages trotting past. I had felt I was taken back to the time of Napoleon our previous visit and I was not disappointed this time. We ordered the six course meal with lobster bisque, salmon, escargot, pear teragon sorbet, dover sole and symphony desert sampler(cream brûlée, chocolate mousse and other delicacies). This was truly a classic event with outstanding service and wonderful ambiance. $74 Canadian each plus tax and tip. This is a "must do" each time I come to this city.

Good cuisine give me a chance for new experience!There is a saying that a good meal may give one a chance to taste her past and welcome the future. I chose this French restaurant to finish my "past and future" thinking, they did a pretty good job with the food and service and I really have a good time.But I think people may agree that one will become more sensitive when she is asked about was she eating alone when she is exactly eating alone; and more sensitive when she is asked about "is that price ok with you" after she totally read and understood what was the menu trying to told the customers. A better service may be giving a proper silence on certain issues.

We went here for the dinner after our small wedding.  The food was excellent quality - not quite what you can get in France but as good as it gets in North America.  The service was topnotch, our wine glasses were always full, courses were well timed so there was no rush to get through the dinner and we could enjoy the beautiful atmosphere and each other's company.  I will say that we had no success in communicating with the restaurant in advance of our wedding.  We went in person once to discuss our options at which time the manager was very helpful and offered us several ways to customize the experience for our guests.  However, when we tried to follow up by phone and email we never managed to catch a person and no one returned our messages.  There was a mishap with our cake delivery, which we ordered from a local patisserie and which was never delivered.  The Bonaparte was informed to expect our cake delivery and didn't notify us in the morning that it never arrived.  While this is primarily the fault of the patisserie, the Bonaparte acknowledged their own small responsibility in this and made it up to us by serving one of their own cakes at no charge.Overall, an excellent fine dining experience with exemplary service.

This is a lovely old world French hotel. High ceilings, exposed brick, HUGE windows. The bath is generous with both a soaking tub and shower. Two sinks, one outside the bathroom-nice extra. It is very quite while being centrally located. About a 8-15 minute walk to McGill Street, Viex Port, Viex Montreal, Place d'Armes, Notre-Dame Basilica,  Montreal Science Centre and more. The staff is friendly and helpful. A full breakfast is included-you chose 3 courses off a menu including-fresh fruit juice, coffee, tea, hot chocolate, fresh fruit salad (great & freshly made with mango, pineapple, grapes, apples, etc), yogurt (would have been MUCH better if poured out if the carton), fresh bread, muffins and croissants (but of course!).  The main dish was crepes, French toast, eggs with sausage and bacon or a choice of several omelets. Everything was very nice. The photos online are exactly what you get-good to know. We reserved thru a hotel search engine and were not sure what we would be getting-we could not be more pleased!

I came to Montreal three years ago. Honestly, the food could not have been better! I had some salmon and noodles, I believe. I only got to be there once on my five-day trip to Mtl. and Quebec City :(( but I will be back in the future! Thank you to the staff for such an incredible experience!

Service took foreverThe maitre d' was rude when we first got there. He didn't sit us as soon as we got there although our table was ready. He sat others before us although we had a reservation. The food was really good though. The price fixe was very worth it. All the food was delicious. The price came out to just under $100US after everything and the tip.

This was the best French restaurant I've ever been to. The service is amazing and the ambience was so relaxing and inviting. We had the taste menu. The froi gras was so delicious I wanted to lick to plate. Had the scallops and shrimp which was to die for and the rack of lamb so moist and tender. Definitely recommend this restaurant if your looking for a French inspired meal. Must try.

If I was forced to complain about Auberge Bonaparte I would be hard pressed to come up with something. My friend and I were staying at the hotel and breakfast is included with the room. I have stayed in many hotels that include breakfast and have come to expect free breakfast = mediocre food at best. Not here! To start we each had the fruit cup....which was lovely. Then I had the French toast. Outstanding in every respect. The crusty French bread, the hint of orange (Grand Marnier?), tiny side of whipped cream, real maple syrup, all cooked to perfection. But wait! There's more! As part of the breakfast menu you can opt for a croissant or other bread. I don't remember the other bread options, once they said croissant I was sold. Also in the bread basket are two mini muffins. I did not have the muffin as I was totally full. My friend ate one and she reports the muffin was excellent. Just to round things out, the breakfast includes orange juice and coffee/tea. I hope I have conveyed my appreciation of the food. (So good I ordered the same thing on back-to-back days.). I would also like to mention the setting is lovely. It didn't hurt sitting at the window overlooking the street and quaint older buildings. And finally, the wait staff was truly outstanding. I am sorry not to call out specific people but everyone was great. As I mentioned breakfast was included with the hotel room. However, for walk-ins it is $15.
